properties.name: Country Music Hall of Fame Museum
properties.description: Posted by Andrew2 222 Fifth Avenue South Nashville, Tennessee Before 1963 the plaques given to Country Music Hall of Fame inductees were kept in the Tennessee State Museum. But in 1963 the Country Music Association announced it\'s plans to build a Country Music Hall of Fame Museum on Music Rowe in Nashville. That same year the state of Tennessee chartered the Country Music Foundation. The CMF was a non-profit, educational organization that was charged with operating the museum. The original museum opened on April 1, 1967 and closed on December 31, 2000. The new 37 million dollar museum (seen above) opened on May 17, 2001. Jimmie Rogers, Hank Williams, and Fred Rose are just of the few who are in the Hall of Fame Museum.

properties.name: Franklin Battlefield (future National Park)
properties.description: Posted by Tellinghistory The Country Club of Franklin Golf Course has been purchased by private preservation groups in Williamson County. The entire golf course will be converted into a restored battlefield on what was the Eastern Flank.

properties.name: Harrison House
properties.description: Posted by Tellinghistory The Harrison House is just south of Winstead Hill on Columbia Pike. General John Bell Hood met in the parlor here with his commanders on the early afternoon of November 30, 1864. His subordinates did not want to make the assault that was forthcoming.

properties.name: Home
properties.description: Posted by Sampsonb My House

properties.name: LP Field
properties.description: Posted by Dcrutch21 Titans Way, Nashville, TNBeing from Tennessee I would have to say that the MIGHTY Tennessee Titans is my favorite team. I have followed the team since they were the Memphis Oilers. I have seen the team go from losing the super bowl by inches, from countless losing seasons, until to now. The Titans are a young up and coming team under the leadership of Vince Young. I believe that with his leadership next season we go all the way. Go Titans!!! Former Tennessee Volunteers: Jesse Mahelona and Albert Haynesworth

properties.name: Nashville Parthenon
properties.description: Posted by Cecilkleakins2600 West End Ave Nashville, TN 37203This replica of the Parthenon in Athens, Greece was built in 1897 for the Tennessee Centennial celebration. Inside stands a 40 foot tall statue of Athena gilt in gold--one of the largest sculptures in the world.

properties.name: The Carnton Plantation
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryCarnton Plantation is a historic home and museum in beautiful Williamson County, Tennessee. It was the largest filed-hospital used after the Battle of Franklin on November 30, 1864. The McGavock\'s owned the home.

properties.name: The Carter Cottin Gin
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryThe site of the Carter Cotton Gin saw some of the fiercest fighting on Nov 30, 1864. At that time, the Carter Farm consisted of 288 acres on the south edge of town bordering the Columbia Pike. Their cotton gin was located 100 yards from the house where eventually the main line of Federal breastworks were constructed.

properties.name: The Carter House
properties.description: Posted by Tellinghistory Now a museum and preserved historical grounds; the farm was originally owned by Fountain Branch Carter in 1864. The site was the epicenter of the Battle between the Union forces under John M. Schofield and Confederate troops under John Bell Hood. The 44th Mississouri was placed right in front of the Carter House, facing south. The 50th Ohio and the 72nd Illinois (Strickland\'s Brigade) were several yards south and in front of the 44th MO.

properties.name: The Hermitage (Home of Andrew Jackson)
properties.description: Posted by Mrmcdougall Andrew Jackson was the first President not to come from aristocracy. Despite his ordinary heritage, he built The Hermitage in Nashville, a stunning Ante-bellum plantation now restored as a museum dedicated to Old Hickory. In addition to revolving exhibits, a film on the history of the President and costumed tour guides, visitors will certainly want to see the first Hermitage cabins, where the former penniless orphan and future political leader and his beloved wife, Rachel, lived before achieving financial and political stability. Designed in the Greek Revival style, The Hermitage was erected in 1819. Many prominent people of the early nineteenth century visited The Hermitage, including the Marquis de Lafayette (May 1825). Rachel died in 1828 and was buried in the Hermitage gardens on the east side of the home. Shortly after her death, Jackson was inaugurated the seventh president of the United States and served two terms. In 1834, while he was in Washington, the Hermitage was severely damaged by fire. In 1837, Jackson had the house rebuilt with the front of the home was painted white to conceal the smoke that blackened the bricks. Jackson died in 1845 and was buried in the gardens next to his beloved Rachel.

properties.name: Winstead Hill
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryJohn Bell Hood stood at this hill looking north toward downtown Franklin on the afternoon of November 30, 1864. He saw the entire Union line spread out from Carter\'s Creek Pike to his left (west), all the way to the east where the 120th Indiana was pressed up against the Nashville-Decatur RR. The rebels organized their troops, some 19,000 here at Winstead, and began the assault of the Union army, having to cross open ground of about two miles before finally reaching the Federal line of defended breastworks.
